awd_titl_txt: Geo Opportunities for Leadership in Diversity (GOLD): Sparks for Change
awd_abstract_narration:
Part I
Sparks for Change is an effort to increase the diversity of the geosciences by improving departmental culture and support of underrepresented minority (URM) faculty, using small groups as change agents. The diversity of faculty in the geosciences remains far below the population as a whole, and this has an effect on attracting and retaining a diverse student body. In this work we focus on improving the retention of underrepresented faculty by using small groups comprised of junior URM faculty interested in broadening participation (BP) efforts (?sparks?), more senior partners in the same departments (?partners?) and experienced broadening participation experts (?sponsors?) to drive change. We acknowledge that an underlying reason for a lack of focus on broadening participation efforts might be the institutional environment, where there is little departmental motivation to recognize or reward BP efforts in tenure and promotion, leading to a culture that does not view BP efforts as important, and an environment where URM faculty do not feel supported. An effective way to tackle this problem is with small groups with appropriate leadership training who are empowered and supported in developing departmental plans for changing the culture of their own department; and application of grounded theory to gather data that supports ongoing change.

Part II
Sparks for Change is centered on a three-day workshop, with follow-up support, that will build a network of scholars focused on broadening participation in the geosciences, provide faculty with the leadership skills necessary to lead a departmental culture change and support for them in developing individualized plans for enacting change. The workshop will bring together ten small groups, comprised of a spark, partner and sponsor, from a range of different institution types, for training in leadership, sharing of broadening participation strategies and practical goal setting. Ongoing support, including evaluation of efforts, development of resources and alliance building will continue to empower the groups to enact change upon return to their institution. Sparks for Change is novel in its incorporation of small group theory as a framework for this change, and will provide us with an understanding of the effectiveness of this approach as well as insight into effective leadership practices and a set of concrete means for changing departmental culture to recognize and reward BP efforts. The goal of the program is to build a network of leaders in BP, a collection of tested strategies for improving departmental support for BP efforts, and a growing number of geoscience departments that are better equipped to attract and retain URM faculty and students, ultimately leading to a more diverse geoscience workforce.

por.por_cntn:
Sparks for Change was a program designed to help support and retain early career minority faculty by empowering leadership and changing departmental culture to better value and embrace diversity, equity and inclusion (DEI) efforts. Eight triads and the Co-PI team, with participants spanning 21 different institutions, were brought together in Boulder Colorado at the Sparks for Change Institute, a 2.5 day workshop in 2017 (note, this was less than the originally planned eleven due to Hurricane's Irma and Maria). Goals of the Institute were to develop leadership skills relevant to their positionality, create action plans specific to individual departments to create culture change that better values and rewards broadening participation efforts, and to build a network of DEI change leaders across multiple institutions. Following the workshop, participants returned to their home institutions to implement their action plans. They were supported with seed funding, a supportive community and ongoing mentorship in their broadening participation efforts (including by sponsors and the program leads).  

As a result of participation in the program; participants articulated growth in leadership skills and confidence in their own capacity as leaders in diversity and inclusion; this was particularly true for the senior Partners who returned to their institutions empowered to both support the Sparks in their department and to use their influence and positionality to advance systemic change. The network created by the program allowed ideas and support to be shared across a range of institution types, and provided ongoing solidarity and support. Elements of the co-developed action plans were taken and implemented, in varying degrees, by participating departments.

Since 2017, the landscape for DEI efforts in the geosciences and higher education has changed dramatically. As a result of the pandemic and national uprising against racism and police brutality sparked by George Floyd's death in 2020, institutions of higher education and the nation have turned a focus toward diversity and inclusion. Sparks for Change participants were well placed to step forward as leaders at this time, and many became prominent through national calls for action, stepping into leadership positions in professional societies and funding agencies, advancing institutional initiatives, writing impactful pieces, and even advising the White House. Departmental action plans that had been slow gained new momentum, and helped shape policy changes in hiring, tenure and promotion, and culture changes that better supported students and faculty of minoritized identities. 

While we cannot attribute these impacts solely to this program, especially as many of our participants were already highly active in DEI activities, a post-reflective survey of the impact of participation in the program showed meaningful change in leadership capacity, sense of self as DEI leaders and ongoing interest in and commitment to diversity initiatives in the geosciences and beyond. Several credited their participation in the program with career support, changes to policies - including those for tenure and promotion and graduate student recruitment - and increases in diversity in their departments. Small groups for DEI advancement have been replicated in several funded programs. Many of the sparks are now gaining or up for tenure, and have been successful in advancing both research and diversity efforts in their careers. This is important, as too many tenure-track faculty from historically underrepresented backgrounds leave higher education before tenure, despite our understanding of the importance of these professors for creating environments where students from historically underrepresented backgrounds can thrive. 

Throughout the life of the program, we have been learning and sharing the experience gained through this program. Recommendations for departments who hire and want to support minoritized faculty, and those advancing DEI initiatives, have been shared through flyers, presentations and workshops at professional conferences, through webinars and at a presentation to the Committee on Equal Opportunities in Science and Engineering (CEOSE), a congressionally mandated advisory committee to the National Science Foundation.  PIs and program participants now lead a range of other inclusion-related initiatives in the geosciences and beyond, better serve and support marginalized students and faculty, and provide leadership and support for ongoing efforts to improve inclusion and diversity across STEM. Despite many changes to program plans and the national landscape since its inception, Sparks for Change has successfully contributed to broadening participation efforts in the geosciences and beyond, and helped support an emerging network of champions for diversity.
